Summary I am passionate about taking care of sick neonates in the intensive care unit and will continue to do so as Kaiser Permanente opens the new San Leandro venue and its larger NICU there. 
I am also equally passionate about bringing my neuroscience expertise to improving the movement and performance of elite athletes (especially golfers but all sports) and am in the process of founding a consulting business, GoaLoGolf, that brings principles of neuroscience to training the elite athlete. Summary Specialties: Adult Pulmonary Medicine in France Summary Specialties: Adult Pulmonary Medicine in France Specialties: Adult Pulmonary Medicine in France Specialties: Adult Pulmonary Medicine in France Experience Resident Physician Alameda County Hospital October 2011  – Present (3 years 11 months) Oakland CA, USA I am currently performing my residency in Internal Medicine at Alameda Health System Hospital (Oakland, CA, USA). Meanwhile, I am very fortunate to be a visiting scholar at Stanford to continue my translational research on a longitudinal cohort of patients with ABPA under the mentoring of Dr. Moss (Professor of Pediatrics at the Lucile Salter Packard Children's Hospital) and Dr. Herzenberg (Professor [Research] of Genetics). Visiting resident Alameda County Hospital April 2014  –  May 2014  (2 months) Bethesda I spent my clinical elective rotation at the NIH/NIAID to learn how to manage patients with rare immunodeficiencies. Given the rarity of these diseases, the management approach was based on experimental molecular therapy designed to specifically target the newly identified immune dysfunction. Clinical and basic research was the foundation of these novel treatments. Clinical Fellow Stanford University School of Medicine July 2012  –  October 2012  (4 months) Stanford Hospital I was seeing patients with allergy or immunodeficiency, under an exemption of the Medical Board of California (exemption 2111), under the supervision of Dr. Sean McGhee, Director of the Allergy and Immunology Fellowship program at Stanford. I became familiar with many conditions such as chronic granulomatous disease, food induced enterocolitis syndrom, toll like receptor deficiency. This experience has confirmed my passion for managing children and adults with Allergy and/or Immunodeficiency. Clinical Research Fellow Stanford University School of Medicine January 2008  –  October 2012  (4 years 10 months) Stanford University School of Medicine In 2008, I returned to Stanford as a post-doctoral fellow to explore the role granulocytes in another atopic disease, food allergy. Under the combined mentorship of Drs. Nadeau, Tirouvanziam, Prs Galli and Herzenberg, I took a leading role in developing direct multi-parameter methods for basophil and eosinophil analysis in whole blood. This work led to several abstracts, publications and patents. I defended my PhD in September 2011, and received the best Honors. At Stanford, now equipped with experience in translational research on CF and allergy, I am currently applying my skills to Cystic Fibrosis-Allergic BronchoPulmonary Aspergillosis (CF-ABPA) under the mentorship of Prof. Moss while performing residency in Internal Medicine. I expect results to lead to a better understanding of CF-ABPA and potentially to the development of a novel, clinically relevant test. Such a test could usher in earlier treatment and better prognosis for CF-ABPA patients. Clinical Fellow Stanford University School of Medicine July 2012  –  October 2012  (4 months) Stanford Hospital I was seeing patients with allergy or immunodeficiency, under an exemption of the Medical Board of California (exemption 2111), under the supervision of Dr. Sean McGhee, Director of the Allergy and Immunology Fellowship program at Stanford. I became familiar with many conditions such as chronic granulomatous disease, food induced enterocolitis syndrom, toll like receptor deficiency. This experience has confirmed my passion for managing children and adults with Allergy and/or Immunodeficiency. Clinical Research Fellow Stanford University School of Medicine January 2008  –  October 2012  (4 years 10 months) Stanford University School of Medicine In 2008, I returned to Stanford as a post-doctoral fellow to explore the role granulocytes in another atopic disease, food allergy. Under the combined mentorship of Drs. Nadeau, Tirouvanziam, Prs Galli and Herzenberg, I took a leading role in developing direct multi-parameter methods for basophil and eosinophil analysis in whole blood. This work led to several abstracts, publications and patents. I defended my PhD in September 2011, and received the best Honors. At Stanford, now equipped with experience in translational research on CF and allergy, I am currently applying my skills to Cystic Fibrosis-Allergic BronchoPulmonary Aspergillosis (CF-ABPA) under the mentorship of Prof. Moss while performing residency in Internal Medicine. I expect results to lead to a better understanding of CF-ABPA and potentially to the development of a novel, clinically relevant test. Such a test could usher in earlier treatment and better prognosis for CF-ABPA patients. Summary Dr. Shengjun Zhang received his MD from Zhengzhou University in 1984 and his MBA in Health Management from Johns Hopkins University in 2010. He participated in clinical fellowship training at Stanford University Sleep Research Center; five years of cardiology postdoctoral training at NIA/NIH; two years of research experience at UMDNJ/RWJMS. In addition to research experiences, Shengjun worked two years in clinical research project management at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine Department of Oncology and two years of international clinical study in infectious diseases (HIV/AIDS) at Johns Hopkins Hospital (HPTN China study project coordinator). Shengjun also has two years of projects management and business development experience at Westat, Inc. and four years of executive-level project director experience at Frontagelab, Inc. Prior to entering the clinical research and trial, he practiced internal medicine and pulmonary in China for twelve years.  
 
Currently, Shengjun serves as director of Clinical Research Center—China for Frontage and a special-appointed professor at Zhengzhou University. Summary I am a licensed clinical and consulting psychologist who is currently working full-time in private practice in San Francisco's Financial district. I provide short and long term psychodynamic, and cognitive behavioral psychotherapy to adolescents, adults, couples and families. I left the University of California, San Francisco's Faculty and Staff Assistance Program to pursue my long-term dream of working in private practice.  
 
I have a strong commitment to understanding diversity and how culture impacts the choices individuals make. In addition, I continue to seek knowledge concerning the interrelatedness of health, illness, and behavior, emotional resiliency, the process of healing, and social influences.  
 
Furthermore I continue to explore and believe in the importance of knowing thyself. I truly believe the journey begins within the self, the more we commit to knowing and accepting ourselves, the more we are able to have healthy relationships because we have nothing to hide and nothing to feel ashamed of. Interpersonal relationships can elicit our most primitive feelings. Learning how to relax into our feelings and open a space to explore and understand what our feelings teach us, we will not be as afraid to be open, and honest regardless of the outcome. 
 
Specialties: Psychodynamic Psychotherapy, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Client-Centered Psychotherapy, Dynamic Brief Therapy Models, Dialectical Behavioral Therapy with a focus on somatic awareness. Specialized training in Mood Disorders, Substance Abuse, Stress Reduction, Emotional Intelligence, Depression, and Anxiety Disorders.
